prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Swiftly walk o'er the western wave,
response:
Swiftly walk o'er the western wave,
Ye mariners of mighty grave;
And when ye comprehend the line,
Watch towers melt in smoke divine.

In this lie truths of Freedom's land,
Where noble souls from chains unbind;
From tyrant's grasp their hands they'll fling,
And breathe the airs of distant climes.

For 'midst the clouds ye soon shall see,
Fields of brave New Zealand's greenery;
And yet not there alone, for wide,
Beyond the ocean's azure tide,

The realms of Liberty extend,
Their mighty march o'er many a strand;
Till seas and continents unite,
In one grand, boundless, free alliance.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Go, go, my naughty girl, and kiss
response:
the moon


Go, go, my naughty girl,
and kiss the moon,
Forget your aching heart,
and be immune.

Forget the tears you've shed,
leave your worries behind,
Don't let your past regrets,
block your mind.

Run through the silent night,
as fast as you can,
Don't look back at the shadows,
on this solemn land.

Leap over the obstacles,
that once seemed too high,
Feel the breeze on your cheeks,
as you touch the sky.

No longer a victim,
of your own despair,
Embrace the freedom,
that's waiting there.

Let the moonlight guide you,
on your adventurous quest,
For in the darkness of night,
your truth shall be manifest.

Remember, my darling,
the power you hold within,
For go, go, my brave girl,
and claim your victory grin.

A chance to start again, with love to become.

So here I sit, beneath its gentle glow,
Embracing night's embracing balm.
For in the darkness, I can truly know,
The yellow moon will guide me home, to calm.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Had ocean been my confidant
response:
, I


Had ocean been my confidant, I would have spoken

Of my endless love and wild dreams,

How every heartbeat echoes my desire,

And how my soul aches for someone who understands.

I would have poured out my fears,

The shadows that haunt my thoughts,

And the weight of expectations I carry on my shoulders.

I'd have confessed my insecurities,

My doubts and my deepest fears,

And asked the vast blue if it could ease my troubled mind.

But alas, the ocean remains a silent witness,

Its waves whispering secrets that I'll never know.

Still, I find solace in its embrace,

In the way it listens without judgment,

In the way it comforts with its timeless strength.

So, to the ocean, I pour out my heart,

Not seeking answers, but finding peace.

For in its depths, I know my worries shall cease.

For in the silence and the darkness, beauty is most complete.

with clouds so fair'

Leaving behind a treasure trove of memories,
For hearts that cherish and hold dear,
The magic of a summer's day in summertime's glory.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: O God! Thou art my God alone;
response:
O dear Lord! I am Thine alone.


O God! Thou art my God alone;
O dear Lord! I am Thine alone.
Thou art my rock and my stronghold,
My Savior, Sustainer, and my throne.

Through trials and tribulations,
Thy grace has been my guide.
In the midst of darkness and despair,
Thy light has led me to abide.

Thou hast heard my every prayer,
And hast brought me through each test.
O mighty and merciful Father,
I place my trust in Thee, never to rest.

In this vast and diverse world,
Thy love is my only treasure.
I pledge my heart and soul to Thee,
To serve and worship Thee forever.

For in Thy presence is fullness of joy,
And in Thy love, there's eternal peace.
O God, my sovereign Lord and King,
With all my heart, I sing praises to Thee.

Author's Note: This poem is an expression of unwavering faith and devotion to God. It reflects the idea that God is the ultimate source of strength, guidance, and love in a person's life, and that our ultimate purpose is to serve and worship Him wholeheartedly. The poem uses religious imagery and language to convey these sentiments, drawing on traditional Christian beliefs about God's nature and relationship with His people.

Lost forever to time and to this abandoned castle's tale

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: There is a law which guarantees
response:
There is a law which guarantees
immunity from prejudice and discrimination,
It's called the Constitution and it applies to all.

The Constitution protects the rights of the individual,
It safeguards freedom of speech and thought,
No one should be judged by their skin color or beliefs,
Equality and justice are what it's all about.

In a diverse society, individual differences must be respected,
No one should be excluded or made to feel inferior,
Let's strive for a world where everyone is treated fairly,
United by common values, not divided by fear.

So let's embrace diversity, celebrate differences,
Let love and understanding guide our actions,
For in the tapestry of humanity, each thread is unique,
And together, we weave a fabric of compassion.

May we always remember the words etched in our charter,
"all men are created equal," a truth that transcends time,
Let's honor this promise, uphold this noble vision,
In doing so, we build a future sublime.

by Denise Doyle

This poem is a tribute to the principles of equality and justice outlined in the Constitution of the United States. It emphasizes the importance of respecting individual differences and working towards a society where everyone is treated fairly and with compassion. The poem also alludes to the timeless phrase "all men are created equal," drawing a connection between the past and the ongoing struggle for equality and justice in modern society.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Three days after the first snowfall of season
response:
Three days after the first snowfall of season,
I step out in the morning chill,
the world around me silent,
a blanket of pristine white covering the ground.

As I walk through the deserted streets,
I can hear the soft crunch of my boots
melting the frost beneath,
each step an invitation to the beauty of the moment.

The sun, through a veil of thin clouds,
casts a gentle glow, highlighting the flakes
that dance and twirl in the cold breeze,
a mesmerizing ballet of nature's creation.

I pause to watch, breath fogging the air,
as a solitary crow calls out from a distant tree,
breaking the serene silence with its loud caw,
yet somehow adding to the enchantment of the scene.

Three days after the first snowfall of season,
the world around me transforms into a tranquil masterpiece,
a temporary pause in the relentless march of time,
where beauty and serenity reign supreme.

I embrace the cold, the stillness, the quiet,
letting the magic of the moment envelop me,
knowing that this fleeting scene will soon give way
to the rebirth of life in the spring's warm embrace.

But for now, I cherish this brief interlude,
a reminder that even in the harshest winter,
there is beauty to be found,
if only we take the time to look.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Some say thronging cavalry, some say foot soldiers,

some say


Some say thronging cavalry, some say foot soldiers, some say
A stealthy sniper’s gaze or bombers from above;
All claim victory for their favored style of war,
But none can truly say which method is most bold.
Each has its own advantages, its strengths and its flaws,
And the outcome hinges on the bravery and the strategy employed.
Whether chariots thundering or armies lined and braced,
The essence of warfare remains a blend of strategy, cunning, and force.

War’s not just about strength or numbers overwhelming the foe,
But the art of outmaneuvering, the mastery of unknowns.
It’s the general’s foresight, the soldier’s resolve,
The courage that sees one through when fear looms large.
So let us remember those who’ve served and sacrificed,
And honor their memory, for their stories are vast and varied.
Through the ages, battles raged, and history marched on,
Carved by the valor and the tragedy of the past.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: I stand alone in darkness,
response:
finding


I stand alone in darkness, finding
a spark within, a sliver of light
guiding my way through shadows, soft whispering
of forgotten dreams, forgotten fights.

Silent tears, like raindrops on glass,
tremble and fall, finding their place
among echoes of pain and the past,
each drop a memory, each one a space.

I wait for the dawn, for clarity's kiss,
for the sun to rise and banish the night,
to warm these cold bones and cleanse the mist,
to give me the strength to take flight.

In darkness, I stand, a solitary tree,
with roots deep in the earth, reaching high,
with branches of hope, lovingly free,
yearning for light and truth to fly.

I am the dreamer, the poet, the soul,
in search of the beauty that's quietly hiding,
in the corners of life, bold and whole,
I find my own path, softly gliding.

So here's to the journey, the battles we face,
to the strength in our hearts, locked tight,
to the courage we muster, to find our own grace,
to the endless sky, where our spirits take flight.

I stand alone in darkness, finding
a spark within, a sliver of light
guiding my way through shadows, softly whispering
of forgotten dreams, forgotten fights.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Love and Sleep
response:
Love and Sleep

Love and Sleep are my escape,
into realms of sweet reprieve,
where peace and quiet wait to embrace,
to heal the scars from the day.

In the cradle of your arms,
I find solace in your sighs,
and drift away on tender sighs,
to a place where worries fade.

Your whispers are lullabies,
singing me to rest,
while your breath, serenity cries,
in a soothing, rhythmic jest.

Love and Sleep, my twin guardians,
in your grace, I find my way,
through the chaos of the world,
to a place where I can stay.

Love and Sleep, oh blessed wings,
carry me through the night,
to a dream where all is serene,
and time stands still in delight.

When morning's light finally breaks,
and I wake to your gentle gaze,
I cherish this stolen moment,
as memories fade into haze.

For in the quiet of the night,
Love and Sleep, you show me grace,
that even in darkest hours,
hope and healing find their place.

Love and Sleep, my guiding stars,
you hold the keys to ease,
in the tapestry of life's design,
in your arms, I truly seize.

So here's to the sweet escape,
to the calm and tender sighs,
to Love and Sleep, my dearest friends,
where peace and joy abide.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: People wish to be settled. Only as long as they are unsettled is there any hope for them.
response:
Surely, some seek to find their place in the world, 
To build a home and nestle in its curl. 
Yet others wander, hearts forever torn, 
Seeking purpose, meaning, something they'd adorn.

For people wish to be settled, yes, it's true,
To have roots growing deep, a life anew.
But only as they're unsettled, restless and free,
Is there any hope for them to truly see.

The storm of change, relentless and fierce,
Sweeps across their path, making them pause and rehearse.
In the chaos and the turmoil, they may find,
The strength to rise, the courage to redefine.

So let us embrace the uncertainty, the unknown,
For within it lies the seed of growth, unshown.
Let's not seek to hide from the tides of fate,
But rather, swim with them, with open gate.

For only as we're unsettled, with minds awake,
Can we break free from the chains of our own making.
Only then we can truly transform and evolve,
Into beings of strength, wise and unforeseen.

So here's to the wanderers, the lost souls seeking,
To those who dare to embrace life's teeming.
For only through the storms, the highs and the lows,
Can we find our true selves and let go.

Now I stand tall, no longer a creature,

that helped me rise from my fallen state.

In the presence of kindness, I have grown,
emerging as a beacon of hope and light.
A reminder to others that within them,
lies the power to defy their plight.

For I was a grovelling creature once,
finding solace in crumbs of bread.
But through kindness, I was reborn,
a testament to the power of the human head.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Well then; the promis'd hour is come at last;
response:
Well then; the promised hour is come at last; 
The weary sun hath got his well-deserv'd repast, 
And sunk beneath the distant hills, to rest.
The air doth softly steal away the light,
And shades steal on the scene, in softest grace;
While hark! the midnight cricket's drowsy song,
Doth tempt the sleepy eyelids to close in their embrace.

The full moon doth ascend with silent pomp,
And reigns upon the night with regal state; 
The stars, with diamond lustre, twinkle bright,
And pave the cloudy canopy with light. 

Now mark yon canvas, as it sweeps along,
The landscape like a living picture grows; 
And hark! how sweetly, with a gentle breath,
The rustling leaves a low, sweet murmur shows.

No more, no more; sweet slumber, be mine own,
Nor let my troubled soul from rest be torn; 
For he who from the bosom of the night,
Can steal such moments of forgetful morn,
May there construct an Eden for his eyes to feast,
And in the moonlit bower find a paradise.

Well then; the promised hour is come at last;
The weary heart doth long for rest;
And I, who oft have wander'd o'er the waste,
Where all things seem to slumber, deep and blest.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: We passed each other, turned and stopped for half an hour, then went our way,
response:
still lost


We passed each other, turned and stopped for half an hour,
then went our way, still lost.
What did we talk about under the dying sun?
Was it the heat or the roads not well traveled?
Or was it dreams that fluttered like forgotten maps?
Silent confessions, shared laughs, or maybe just the silence?
In that fleeting moment, we were strangers no more,
just souls searching in the vastness of this life.

We parted with a nod, a smile perhaps,
but somewhere deep inside,
a connection stirred, subtle yet sure,
like two lone stars crossing paths in the night sky.

Now, as days turn to weeks, and weeks to months,
I often wonder about that unknown stranger,
what path they tread, what trials they face,
and if ever, our fates will entwine once again,
leading us to a destination yet unknown.

So, here's to that half-hour pause in our journey,
a brief intermission in the endless quest,
a chance encounter that left an imprint,
a reminder of the beauty found in the unknown.

And if by chance, we meet again,
let us pause, reflect, and maybe, just maybe,
continue our conversation under another dying sun.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: Before me stands I see,
response:
before me lies...

Before me stands I see,
a mirror reflecting me,
before me lies a path,
where choices wait to be.

Choices whisper soft and sweet,
urging me to take a seat,
and ponder life's complex treat,
each moment rich, complete.

Left is doubt, uncertainty,
the fear of the unknown,
right beckons with certainty,
hope, courage, calm, shown.

I close my eyes, take a deep breath,
and choose where I'll trod forth,
a step to the left, or to the right,
my destiny, my worth.

The choice is mine, I must decide,
with heart and mind in sync,
for every choice shapes my tide,
with time, I'll truly know its link.

So here's to choices we make,
each decision, big or small,
may they lead us to our wake,
and guide us through it all. 

--- © Jen Derrick 2017

For my friend Lisa, who recently found herself at this crossroad of life, and for everyone who faces their own personal path of choices.  *hugs* May your choices lead you to happiness and fulfillment.

The following line, “War’s a game for Cathars and Jews,” introduces specific historical and religious groups that faced persecution and devastation during times of war, complicating the speaker’s light-hearted tone and inviting the reader to question their interpretation of war.

War's a shadow in the dark,  
Chasing ghosts, forever stark.

Nightmare screams, silent scream.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: The Beaver's Lesson
response:
The Beaver's Lesson
In still pond's reflection, I saw my true self
A muddied imprint, a life misdirected
Yet, the beaver taught me, by nature's example
To mend and improve, with resolve and care

The water's surface, once pristine, disrupted
By the very efforts I sought to perfect
But patient beaver, with his chisel sharp
Dug deeper channels, to let water flow anew

Through hardships, I wandered aimlessly
My heart, burdened with heavy distress
The beaver's lesson, so clear and true
Forged from wet earth, a foundation anew

The pond reclaims its calm serenity
The path, now open, beckons me forward
I follow the beaver's unwavering guidance
To sculpt a life, resilient and unscarred

The Beaver's Lesson
To heal wounds, be patient, let nature mend
To build bridges, start with sturdy roots
In every hardship, find a lesson learned
The beaver's wisdom, my guiding truth.

The poem reflects on personal growth and self-improvement through the metaphor of a beaver's actions in nature. It emphasizes the importance of patience, resilience, and learning from nature and experiences.

Feel free to adjust or expand upon this theme to better fit your intended message or vision for the poem.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY
response:
A poet loses his power for poetry,
His muse retreats, in silent fury,
Away from the hustle and chaos,
Her delicate wings tattered and forlorn.

The poet wanders through the empty streets,
A lost soul in a concrete jungle,
No sonnets to whisper to the wind,
No verses to dance with the rain.

Days turn into nights, into months,
The poetic flow dries up like autumn leaves,
His heart a barren wasteland,
Yearning for the touch of the divine.

But then, in a moment of stillness,
A glimmer of hope in the darkness,
The poet realizes the power within,
Not just in the words, but in his will.

He picks up his pen, battered and bruised,
And on a blank page, he starts anew,
His words now carry the weight of struggle,
Uplifting spirits, breaking through.

For a poet's true power lies not in perfection,
But in the rawness of his human experience,
In the courage to face his fears,
And in the resilience to keep writing, no matter what.

So let the lost poet find his voice again,
In the echoes of battles won and lost,
For poetry is not just a gift,
But a testament to the human soul's cost.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: 8 years old
response:
, lost my teeth

8 years old, lost my teeth,
Left them under my pillow,
Thought I’d receive a little gift,
But what I got was a cold steel drill.
Fear rushed through my body,
Tears brimmed up my eyes,
No sweet treat for me this time,
Just pain and the sound of metal drilling through my gums.
Mom assured me it was okay,
Dad tried to joke it away,
But inside, my heart was breaking,
At the dentist’s office each day.
The dentist, with his friendly smile,
Seemed not to understand,
That to a child, this was a trial,
Something so utterly grand.
The fear of the drill, the pain, the noise,
The bright lights glaring down,
All because I was due for some lost tooth joys,
But ended up with a fearsome frown.
So here’s to all the kids out there,
Who have faced this trial with tears,
May they find comfort in knowing,
Their bravery is beyond compare.
For some day they’ll look back and smile,
Remembering this challenging time,
And knowing they faced it head-on,
With courage that will shine.

prompt: Please write a poem starting with the following line: How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
response:
in thy fair bosom ..

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
In thy fair bosom buried beauteous truth!
How soon hath Time, the rust of precious life,
Stolen thy jeweled hours, set enbriar'd free!
How soon hath Time his gray icy fingers spread,
Upon the rosebud beauty of thy years!
Outwitted, outstripped by Time's deceitful pace,
And none to chide or pray thy flight to cease.

But O, for not that hour of midnight dread
When, soul and body riven asunder,
In Time's embrace, thou feel'st thy life-blood drain,
Nor yet that dreadful hour when Death draws near
And all the pulses of thy heart stand still;
But those lost moments, happy as they were,
The silent laughter, the unspoken sigh,
The gentle touch, the sweet embrace that fled.

For these, in hopeless grief I weep anew,
And to the shadows mourn my youth's departure;
Yet hold my tears in check, for thou art with me still,
Though changed in form and garb, in spirit thou art true.
The heart, once fired by love's celestial flame,
Can never wholly die, but finds a home
In memories sweet, in dreams of joy divine,
In every smile that echoes in the heart.

So here's to thee, my love, my youth, my life,
